lines:
6 December, 1917.

Mr. S. S. Karen 
39 Peterboro St.

Boston, Mass.

My dear Kwan:

My absence over the waekkend prevented me from ansvering your

letter of November 29th and also I am told from catching & glimpse of you

when you were in Andover recently.

I am SOVIF

ough that I missed you,

for it is a long time since we have had a good chat together. Can't you

come out again in the near future, and give me a chance to make amenas?

Your suggestion about the Chinese plaf is a most interesting

one. I feel pretty sure that we coulê get out a fairly good crowd here, 
up at the Peabody House at least, and in that was enable you to collect 
something towards your flood sufferers' fund. I didn't realize that the

flood was so bad, or that it covered places like Tsing Hua with which I am

more or less familiar .

Do tyto come out. I want to talk over your om affairs with 
jou, and also those of Tony Lee from whom I have not heat for a long while 
and who apparently has given up the attempt to straighten out his finances. 
I dislike exceedingit to take the matter up with his father, but evidently 
I shall have to do so if I don't get some satisf action out of Tommy himself 
in the near future. The matter has tm on this wa now for several years, 
and I don't think that Tom ºg father ought to stand this extra and unneces -
sat interest charge. Can't you come out in time to take dinner with me? 
All you need to do is to give me warning when to expect you. 
With best wishes, believe me always

Sincerely your friena,
raw: 6 December, 1917. Mr. S. S. Karen 39 Peterboro St. Boston, Mass. My dear Kwan: My absence over the waekkend prevented me from ansvering your letter of November 29th and also I am told from catching & glimpse of you when you were in Andover recently. I am SOVIF ough that I missed you, for it is a long time since we have had a good chat together. Can't you come out again in the near future, and give me a chance to make amenas? Your suggestion about the Chinese plaf is a most interesting one. I feel pretty sure that we coulê get out a fairly good crowd here, up at the Peabody House at least, and in that was enable you to collect something towards your flood sufferers' fund. I didn't realize that the flood was so bad, or that it covered places like Tsing Hua with which I am more or less familiar . Do tyto come out. I want to talk over your om affairs with jou, and also those of Tony Lee from whom I have not heat for a long while and who apparently has given up the attempt to straighten out his finances. I dislike exceedingit to take the matter up with his father, but evidently I shall have to do so if I don't get some satisf action out of Tommy himself in the near future. The matter has tm on this wa now for several years, and I don't think that Tom ºg father ought to stand this extra and unnecessat interest charge. Can't you come out in time to take dinner with me? All you need to do is to give me warning when to expect you. With best wishes, believe me always Sincerely your friena,

metadata.name: Phillips Academy
metadata.abstract: Letter apologizing for missing Kwan's visit, encouraging him to present the Chinese play to raise flood relief funds, and inviting him to visit to discuss Tommy Lee's finances.
metadata.note_acquisition: Phillips Academy Archives and Special Collections received the letters and materials of Sung Sing Kwan from Alfred E. Stearns in ____(date)
metadata.note_preferred-citation: From The Trustees of Phillips Academy.
metadata.collection: Head of School (Stearns) correspondence with Chinese alumni
